title: 106_hr4626
content: The "Debt Buy-Down Act" is designated for the reduction of public debt under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It introduces a new part for the designation of amounts towards reducing the public debt. Every individual with adjusted income tax liability can designate up to 10 percent of their liability to reduce the public debt. This designation must be made when filing the tax return and is subtracted from the income tax liability. The amendments in this section apply to taxable years ending after the enactment date. A new section is added to the Internal Revenue Code for a Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by appropriations and transfers designated for public debt reduction. The Secretary of the Treasury can use the funds to pay off or buy back federal government obligations, excluding certain specific funds. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund in the Department of Defense Military Retirement Fund cancels and retires obligations paid with fund amounts, prohibiting reissuance. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for the subchapter. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund in the Department of Defense Military Retirement Fund cancels and retires obligations paid with fund amounts, prohibiting reissuance. The amendments made by this section apply to amounts received after the date of the enactment of this Act. Part C of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended by inserting a new section for sequestration to reduce the public debt. Sequestration equivalent to estimated aggregate amount designated under section 6097 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for the last taxable year ending one year before the beginning of that session of Congress shall occur within 15 days after Congress adjourns. Sequestration occurs based on the estimated aggregate amount designated under section 6097 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Each account of the United States is reduced by a calculated dollar amount. Sequestration reduces resources in accounts by a uniform percentage to carry out subsection (a) permanently. Certain accounts are exempt from reduction, including benefits under the Social Security Act, retired pay for uniformed services members, government employee retirement benefits, net interest payments, and specific accounts. Sequestration reduces resources in accounts by a uniform percentage permanently, exempting certain accounts like the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and National Credit Union Administration. Amendments are made to Section 254 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 regarding reports. The Department of Treasury report to Congress estimates income tax designated under section 6097 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments include adding sequestration to reduce public debt and requiring reports on sequestration for the budget year. The preview reports will include estimates for the aggregate amount designated under section 6097 of the Internal Revenue Code, reductions required under section 253A, and the sequestration percentage needed to achieve the reduction. Additionally, there will be reports on sequestration to reduce the public debt. The final reports on sequestration to reduce the public debt will contain all necessary information as required in the public debt taxation designation report. The amendments made by this section regarding sequestration to reduce the public debt will not have any effect after the first fiscal year with no public debt.
